As an essential raw material for fertilizer production and promising green fuels, ammonia is significant to the national economy and social development. Recently, nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) towards ammonia under mild conditions has received intensive attention due to environmental friendliness and low energy consumption, compared to the rigorous and contaminative Haber-Bosch process. However, as current research deepens, some fatal challenges emerged in this field–not only high volatility and low repeatability but false–positive results, casting serious doubts about its prospects. In this review, we summarized and discussed some potential factors that possibly induce false-positive results for accurate ammonia quantification, including the aspects of catalyst materials, experimental process, and quantification methods. And corresponding methods to eliminate these effects are also summarized. Furthermore, a promising protocol and several control principles are proposed to eliminate potential errors during ammonia quantification. This review establishes a paradigm base in NRR research field toward more accurate ammonia quantification. Graphical Abstract The potential factors affect credible ammonia quantification in nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) towards ammonia, including the aspects of catalyst materials, experimental process, and quantification methods, and how they disturb the final results of ammonia quantification. Keywords Nitrogen reduction reaction Ammonia quantification False positives Contamination Isotope 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is widely utilized in fertilizer production and industrial chemicals globally, and its annual consumption is enormous [1,2]. According to statistics by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), fertilizer contributes more than 40% to the increase of grain production in the world. On top of that, thanks to its high hydrogen content (17.6 wt%) and energy density (4.32 kWh L−1/6.25 kWh kg−1 at –33.3 °C and 1 bar), ammonia has broad prospects as a clean energy carrier and fuel [3]. As a result, the synthetic ammonia industry plays a pivotal role in the national economy and social development. Current ammonia synthesis in the industry relies on the traditional Haber-Bosch process, in which nitrogen and hydrogen react chemically to produce ammonia through a heterogeneous iron-based catalyst [4]. However, due to the reversibility of reaction (N2 + 3H2 ⇋ 2NH3) and strong N≡N bond energy (941 kJ mol−1), high temperature of 450 to 500 °C and high pressure of up to 200 atm are required in Haber-Bosch industry to push the reaction forward [5]. The harsh operating condition results in massive energy consumption and CO2 emission, further worsening the global warming problem [6]. Under the global background of energy crisis and environmental problems, it is urgent to develop an alternative process of ammonia synthesis with green chemistry and high efficiency under ambient conditions [7]. In this context, developing green and more efficient ammonia synthesis technologies driven by renewable energy have received intensive attention. Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) powered by photocatalysis and electrocatalysis is considered as the most critical and promising way [8,9]. Figs. 1(a) and (b) illustrated the electrocatalytic NRR (eNRR) and photocatalytic NRR (pNRR) processes. In these two strategies, NH3 is synthesized by catalytic reduction of N2 in an aqueous electrolyte under mild conditions. The whole conversion mechanism is a multi-electron transfer process and involves multiple transient states. The electrons in eNRR are derived from direct current while in pNRR are originated from photoelectron in the conduction band generated by the transition of electrons in the valence band under photon excitation, and their overall reaction is [10]: N2 + 6H+ + 6e− → 2NH3 With NRR catalysts of low surface absorption energy for N2, the dissociation of N≡N triple bond and addition of proton from the aqueous electrolyte to N atom synergistically contribute to the final ammonia generation [11]. Typically, the hydrogen source is derived from water electrolysis, powered by renewable electricity. Therefore, the strategy of eNRR and pNRR cuts down carbon footprint due to their abundant raw materials and moderate reaction conditions [12]. Besides, compared to Harbor's complex reactor and centralized production, the simplified reactor design and distributed production also promise a bright future for eNRR and pNRR [13]. Unfortunately, due to slow adsorption kinetics of N2, difficult N≡N bond splitting, and serious hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the NH3 yield rate (NYR) and faradic efficiency (FE) of pNRR and eNRR are both low at present [14,15]. Nevertheless, benefiting from the development of various catalysts and solution designs, the NYR and FE of NRR systems have constantly been broken and updated in recent years [16–18]. Especially in terms of faradic efficiency, the FE value has undergone an explosive increase from less than 10% to more than 60% in just four years, from 2018 to 2022 [19–27], ((Fig. 1(c))) which has raised the crisis of confidence about the prospect of NRR research. The fundamental basis is the extremely low NYR in NRR–commonly nanomolar/micromolar levels. It is challenging to guarantee that the obtained product NH3 is entirely from the reduction of highly stable N2 [3]. Trace contamination during the NRR process may seriously affect NH3 quantification results, leading to the high volatility and low repeatability of quantification NRR studies, as well as false-positive results [28–30]. Therefore, the premise of further development in this field is to guarantee a more accurate NH3 quantification result of pNRR and eNRR by a rigorous NRR test process. Contamination sources and uncertainties in a complete NRR testing are mainly originated from three stages: before testing, during testing, and the final quantification process, which involves multiple aspects, including impurity from reactants and contaminated experimental devices, intrinsic defects of various quantification methods, and even some subtle quantitate instrument errors. ((Fig. 1(d))) Herein, we discussed how these potential factors disturbed the final results of ammonia quantification and summarized the reported strategies for eliminating the corresponding effects. What's more, based on our research experience in NRR, a rigorous protocol suggested in NRR field is proposed in this review. At last, we put forward an outlook toward the future development of this field. This review points to some critical issues and establishes a paradigm base of credible ammonia quantification that will promote the benign development of NRR research. 2 Nitrogen contamination during catalyst synthesis and transfer storage 2.1 Nitrogen-impurities introduction during catalyst synthesis According to literature reports, nitrogen contaminations are always inevitably brought into the NRR catalyst in catalyst preparation, including N-containing species in the environment, precursors, or raw materials [31–35]. Despite the relatively small input amount, it is non-negligible compared with the current level of synthetic ammonia in the NRR system. Li et al. [36] closely monitored the presence of high levels of nitrides-N from some commercial metal oxides and metallic irons, which are both frequently employed in the synthesis of catalyst materials in different NRR systems. Worst of all, the contamination value is up to 7297 ± 99 × 10−6 g mol−1, which is sufficient to affect the accuracy of the quantification results [36]. (Table 1 ) In addition to impurities from raw materials, nitrogenous pollutants are also susceptive to be introduced during the next catalyst synthesis procedures, such as trace residues caused by reaction media (inorganic nitrogen oxides, nitric acid, and organic amines) or from laboratory environment pollution. Luo et al. [37] prepared palladium nanosheets (PD-NSs) as eNRR catalyst. During the nitrogen reduction experiment, they unexpectedly found that the experimental result was false positive through Ar blank control experiment and eventually determined that the synthesis process of PD-NSs inadvertently introduced NO x pollutants (Fig. 2 ). In that case, they proposed an electrochemical pre-reduction strategy to eliminate residual or adsorbed NO x pollutants in catalysts. The method is specified as follows: before NRR tests, the carbon cloth loaded with polluted catalysts was immersed in the electrolytes for two hours, followed by pre-reduction at different potentials to remove NO x ions, and the NRR tests were performed using reduced catalysts in a new electrolyte with no reductive polluted products finally [37]. 2.2 Nitrogen-doped catalytic carbon materials Heterogeneous atom doping was considered a promising strategy for enhancing the electrochemical catalytic performance of NRR catalysts [38,39]. This method can regulate the catalyst's energy band structure, giving the catalyst higher charge density and higher intrinsic conductivity but lowering the adsorption energy barrier of the reactants on the surface of the catalyst and thus reducing the overpotential of the electrocatalytic reaction [40]. Typically, it can be divided into two types: metal (Co, Mo, Ni, Mg, Cr, V, and so on) and nonmetal (N, S, O, B, P, and so on) heteroatoms [41]. It should be noted that N-doped carbon material carriers have the potential danger of forming NH3 at large reduction potential and interfere with the amount of NH3 products measured in the experiment [42]. Consequently, it has aroused much interest in the scientific community about the stability evaluation of different types of doped N (pyrrolic-N, pyridinic-N, or graphitic-N) in the carbon materials under electrification and which of them is responsible for NH3 formation in the electrocatalytic NRR [43–45]. Zhang et al. [42] discovered that doped pyridinic-N atoms in alfalfa-derived porous graphitic carbon are unstable to detach from the surface and then reduced to NH3 by a hydrogenation process during NRR, compared to the pyrrolic-N and graphitic-N. ((Fig. 3(a) )) Similarly, Zhou et al. [45] confirmed that pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N are prone to break away and hydrogenate to form ammonia from chitosan-derived N-doped porous carbon (NPC), resulting in an unreliable result of ammonia yield rate. What's more, they put forward a single-atomic anchoring strategy (Co/Mo-N x /NPC). From this strategy, the metal-N x bond can anchor the exposed active N atom by the strong interaction between the metal atom and coordinated N, efficiently suppressing the decomposition of doped N and also offering more reactive sites. Ultimately, the enhanced electrochemical NRR performance was obtained [45]. ((Fig. 3(b))) Besides N-doped carbon materials, some labile nitrogenous catalytic materials might be akin to decomposing under an applied bias to liberate nitrogen-containing species during the NRR experiments [46,47]. It should be noted that the release of nitrogenous species from some labile nitrogen-containing catalytic materials is not always a negative result, but may produce dynamic nitrogen vacancies to promote the adsorption and reduction of dinitrogen. The source of product ammonia can be accurately detected by rigorous isotope tracing experiments, thus excluding the potential risk of false positive results [48]. 2.3 Control of storage environment and transfer process In order to improve the adsorption characteristics of N2 or reaction intermediates, nanomaterials with strong gas adsorption ability have been powerful choices as most NRR catalysts [49]. Paradoxically, along with reduced reaction energy barrier and improved catalytic reaction performance, it also brings an infaust and potential challenge: the equally strong adsorption to gas pollutants. In that case, it stands a loophole that NO x pollutants or other contaminations are adsorbed into the catalysts from the air environment or human breath in the catalyst transfer and storage process. Even the end product ammonia may be no exception because of its high airborne content, which would more directly interfere with the validity of quantitative results. On account of severe gas adsorption pollution, a rigorous transfer and storage protocol needs to abide. The transfer time of the catalyst should be controlled as short as possible to minimize the exposure time of NRR catalysts to the ambient environment, further reducing the adsorption amount of NH3 or NO x species, while as-prepared catalysts are requisite to be reserved under vacuum or clean argon atmosphere in the closed system in subsequent storage [3]. Moreover, the involved container must check and clean to exclude possible ammonia residues and avoid employing some plastic vessels with ammonia [50]. Given the above discussions, the catalysts should be inspected and purified before NRR tests. Generally, before NRR tests, an Ar control experiment, which is fed by Ar gas instead of N2 gas under the same operating conditions as NRR tests, such as gas flow rate, voltage/current, reaction solution, etc., can be performed to determine whether pollutants exist in the catalyst [51]. For purification methods, in addition to the above electrochemical pre-reduction, a thorough rinse of catalyst with ultra-pure water or acids (except for nitric acid) multiple times can also effectively decrease the contaminations before its use in NRR tests [52]. Symes's group pre-washed 50 mg of Sn phthalocyanine five times with 10 mL ultrapure-grade water each time and demonstrated at least two such washes were required to control the level of ammonia in the solution down to a steady baseline value [46]. If the NRR catalyst is determined to be unclean, it also could be purified through recrystallization or annealing at an appropriate temperature [53]. More directly and reliably, nitrogen-free catalysts should be preferred for the same performance as other nitrogenous ones. 3 Nitrogen pollution during NRR experiment 3.1 Reaction solution 3.1.1 Aqueous solutions Most NRR systems in an ambient environment are operated in aqueous solutions. The measurement of ammonia production is always accompanied by volatility and uncertainty due to extremely low ammonia production rates and the influence of nitrogen contamination. From the structure characteristic of ammonia, ammonia is a small and polar molecule, and thus it easily dissolves into the water with an aqueous solubility of 482 g L−1 at 24 °C (Eq. (1)) [54,55]. The value is valid for either form of ammonia (ammonium, NH4 + or ammonia, NH3), while the assigned amount of either form is heavily dependent on the pH of solution. As a result, ascribed to the ubiquity of ammonia dissolved in aqueous solutions, a background level of ammonia always exists, which is usually deducted as the blank in ammonia quantification [56]. However, if the value is too large, there will be more errors in the final results. As known to us, both reduction of gaseous (N2O, NO, NO2) and ionic (NO2 − and NO3 −) oxidized forms of nitrogen are superior to N2 (NRR) in forming NH3 regardless of thermodynamics or kinetics favor [3]. Unfortunately, beyond soluble ammonia in the early or later stage, ionic NO x impurities might be present in the solutions, including solvents, salts, additives, etc. Qiao and colleagues detected and quantified trace nitrate and nitrite contamination by simple universal spectrophotometry in some commercial lithium salts, like Li2SO4 and LiClO4, commonly used as electrolyte components in the electrocatalytic NRR systems. (Table 2 ) Since that, they adopted a high-temperature annealing method, removing nitrates and nitrites quickly and efficiently [53]. The work also raises the alarm for the future selection and impurity removal of chemicals in the electrolytes. Similarly, a rigorous NRR process also require the ultra-purity of water. The resistivity of deionized water should be greater than 10 MΩ·cm@25 °C, and the ready-to-use principle of deionized water should be followed. In addition, in order to provide purer deionized water, it is also necessary to carry out regular checks on the pure water machine and regular replacements of its filters. (1) NH3(g) + H2O(l) ↔ NH4 + (aq) + OH− (aq) 3.1.2 Non-aqueous solutions On account of the stability and poor absorbability of nitrogen molecules, and even theoretically predicted voltage far lower than the thermodynamic potential to initiate NRR, HER in aqueous NRR has been a notorious parasitic reaction in which protons snatch electrons that should be supplied to reduce nitrogen [57]. And this parasitic reaction renders a weaker FE and NYR [58,59]. In order to inhibit this severe issue, researchers attempted to adopt a straightforward and potentially efficient solution system–nonaqueous aprotic media to decrease proton activity [60–63]. Especially, lithium-mediated nitrogen reduction reaction (LMNRR), which uses lithium salt as the active substance and THF as the solvent in most studies [64], exhibits a high NYR and good experimental reproducibility compared to other systems [13]. Akin to the aqueous system, extraneous nitrite and ammonia are still possible to exist in nonaqueous solutions. Simonov et al. [65] studied electrochemically induced generation of extraneous nitrite and ammonia in organic solutions during nitrogen reduction experiments and demonstrated the continuous detection of NO x in the solutions. ((Fig. 4(a) )) As the previous lines already suggest, active Li salt indispensable to LMNRR still has the risk of being impure or polluted, and the purchase channel of commercial lithium salt should be carefully chosen. Besides, some organic nitrogen solvents or other additives such as amine salts, pyrrole, etc., should be carefully considered in the reaction solution, which may have the risk of converting into ammonia nitrogen and then interfering with the results during the final quantification process [66]. To obtain as clean reaction solutions as possible, whether in aqueous or nonaqueous systems, N2/Ar is usually bubbled in the solution for minutes to drive off the potential interfering gas (such as NO x , NH3) before the actual NRR tests begin. Moreover, we think that not only catalyst purification, electrochemical pre-reduction may also be applicable for reaction solution purification. The detailed method has been stated in Part 2.1. 3.2 Impact assessment of experimental device materials The devices of the whole NRR system normally demand several parts, including a gas circuit, reaction cell, absorption trap, etc. To successfully build up an integrated reaction system, it is inevitable to involve the usage of the following experimental device materials: cells, caps, flow lines (such as PTPE tubes), traps, as well as electrocatalytic electrodes, ion-exchange membranes (such as Nafion), electrode holders (such as PEEK), and so on. Consideration of the strong polarity of ammonia, it always occurs on many substance surfaces and then dissolves into the solution during the NRR tests, with no exception of NO x [67]. This will lead to possible contaminations in the initial device building and hinder accurate quantification of the ammonia yield rate afterward. In Luo's work, they discovered high levels of pollution in traditional Nafion membranes used in almost all NRR works and switched to an almost pollution-free Celgard 3501 membrane as an alternative to decrease the adsorption and release of ammonia by the membrane [37] ((Fig. 4(b))). Apart from what has been referred to above, Sun and coworkers also strikingly observed an ultrahigh ammonia amount of ∼0.21 μg mL−1 from the new nitrile gloves widely worn in our practical operations. They thus suggested the alternative polyethylene gloves with less ammonia contamination for usage [50] ((Fig. 4(c))). As a consequence, to control the ammonia contamination in the experimental device materials, all materials above involved in NRR tests should be possessed of pre-treatment, specific as thorough cleaning and proper storage. For example, 1 mol L−1 H2SO4 is recommended to rinse all accessories to be used [56,68]. When in vacancy, soak them in sulfuric acid or ultrapure water, and wash them thoroughly with ultrapure water or reaction solution again three times before next use [52]. What's more, boiling the experimental device materials in ultrapure water for ten minutes is also suggested as an effective pre-treatment method [12]. 3.3 Nitrogen source pollution in gas cylinder or open atmosphere What's most obvious and understandable, the gas supply is one of the leading characters in NRR process, yet it is a potential big hidden pollution source. NO x pollution is often detected in most nitrogen cylinders, even the highest levels of purity provided by the commercial suppliers, which is more easily reduced to ammonia than N2 in terms of theory and experience. Consequently, nitrogen source pollution in gas cylinders may cause false positives for ammonia quantification [3] (Table 3 ). What's worse, this problem can be greatly exacerbated by changes in the actual purity of the gas supply between batches [52]. Not only the gas cylinder but also the gas pollution in the open environment can not be underestimated. For instance, ambient air contains ammonia in the range of 0.05–250 × 10−6 g mL−1 [69], and even human breath contains 0.3–3.0 × 10−6 g mL−1 ammonia [70]. However, ammonia and nitrogen oxide content under distinct environmental conditions may vary a lot, and the degree of error has a big difference accordingly, specific as a positive correlation. Therefore, it is imperative to detect and eliminate the existing impurities in the gas source, which disturbs the real results to a large extent. First, it is necessary to test the purity of the gas source before NRR experiment. Nitrogen control experiments at open potential can be performed to study ammonia contamination in the feed stream, while the gas chromatography (GC) spectra can be shown the existing conditions of NO x contaminations [19]. Then, to mitigate foreign pollution, such as reducible NO x or other related nitrogen compounds, before feed gas enters the reaction cell, additional purification must be executed with appropriate adsorbents. Take reduced copper adsorbent as an example, which is achieved via the reduction of Cu oxide in the mixed H2/Ar gas, feed gas is introduced to the reaction system after passing through the reduced copper trap to reduce adventitious contamination [71]. In addition, other purification methods include, before entering into the NRR cell, nitrogen gas flows through an acid and alkaline trap, a drying tube in sequence to remove the possible NH3, NO3 −, NO x , and water vapor, respectively [72]. Furthermore, it is suggested to carry out the NRR experiments in closed systems to insulate the possible external contaminations from the open environment. 4 Uncertainties during the process of ammonia quantitation To date, most reports are dedicated to solving the adverse factors of external pollutants for accurate quantification of ammonia in the NRR systems but often ignore the inherent deficiency of the current methods for ammonia detection and quantification. These methods are typical of spectrophotometry/colorimetry [73], ion chromatography [74], fluorescence [75], ammonia ion-selective electrodes [76], 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR) [77], and the indispensable 15N isotope labeling [71], etc. For simple ammonia-water solution, it cannot be denied that these methods have a wide detection range and high accuracy for ammonia quantification, while for the commonly nanomolar/micromolar concentration levels of NH3 in many photocatalytic or electrocatalytic experiments, the validity of these methods can be negatively influenced by uncertainties in the solution samples, such as pH value, NH4 + concentration or interference effect (impurity ions, certain solvents, and other molecules, especially nitrogenous molecules), etc. [78]. Herein, we choose several more familiar methods in most of NRR systems studied as a paradigm to scrutinize the interference factors for ammonia quantification, including spectrophotometric/colorimetric assays, 1H NMR spectroscopy, and 15N isotope labeling method. 4.1 Spectrophotometric/colorimetric assays Due to the low cost, high sensitivity, and facile operation, spectrophotometric methods are widely used for NH3 quantification in the NRR systems, in which Nessler's reagent (NR) and indophenol blue (IB) are the two most commonly applied in ammonia quantification [77] ((Fig. 5(a) )). In the NR method, iodide and mercury ions under alkaline conditions react with free ammonia (NH3) or ammonium (NH4 +) to produce a reddish-brown colloidal compound with strong absorption over a wide wavelength range. The absorbance of the complex is proportional to the content of ammonia, and the wavelength for measurement is located in the 410–425 nm range [73]. The IB method works well for aqueous and nonaqueous systems. It is based on the Berthelot reaction, where a phenolic compound reacts with ammonia and hypochlorite in an alkaline solution to form an indophenol-like dye [73]. The indophenol product has a strong visible light absorption at 630–720 nm, allowing for ammonia quantification by ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy [79]. Nowadays, as a modified IB method, the salicylate method is more widely used in the NRR tests, in which nontoxic sodium salicylate is substituted for phenol [80,81]. In general, the main factors affecting the accuracy of spectrophotometric analysis include acidity/alkalinity, chroma, turbidity, etc. If the sample is cloudy or colored, it can be treated by pre-distillation or flocculation precipitation [82]. For NRR systems, the operation environment is normally divided into different acidity/alkalinity, like 0.05 mol L−1 H2SO4 or 0.1 mol L−1 HCl for acid, 0.1 mol L−1 phosphate buffer solution (PBS), or 0.1 mol L−1 Na2SO4 for neutral, and 0.1 mol L−1 KOH for alkaline [52]. From the reaction mechanism of determination of ammonia by colorimetric method, the pH value of sample undoubtedly has a direct influence on the determination result when hydroxide ion is involved in both two reactions of colorimetric methods. Too low or too high pH will result in incomplete color rendering or sample turbidity. Nevertheless, for different colorimetric methods, the degree of impact may differ widely. Zhang's group found better linearity of low-concentration ammonia in 0.5 mol L−1 Na2SO4 (R 2 = 0.9960) between absorption intensity and the concentration of ammonia in contrast to 0.05 mol L−1 H2SO4 and 0.1 mol L−1 KOH for NR method. For IB method, the correlation coefficient is remarkably high in all three solutions, ((Fig. 5(b))) whereas at higher ammonia concentration (>2.94 × 10−5 mol L−1) and in acidic media, the correlation is less applicable [83]. Therefore, if the pH value is too low or too high, it is better to use sodium hydroxide or sulfuric acid to adjust the pH value to a suitable range before the quantification test [84,85]. Except for the pH of the solution, the concentration of ammonium salt significantly affects the accurate detection for spectrophotometric methods. Generally speaking, the accurate ammonia detection range of NR and IB methods should be limited to between 0.02 to 5 and 0.02 to 1.25 × 10−6 g mL−1, respectively [73]. Nonetheless, both of them is not optimistic under low-concentration ammonia, showing a poor linear relationship seen from fitting results, particularly below 0.2 × 10−6 g mL−1 [83]. What's more, metal ions leaching from the NRR catalyst layer may act as interferents in the spectrophotometric methods. On the one hand, some dissolved metal ions will react with Nessler's reagent to produce colored compounds in acidic media, such as Ru3+, Fe2+, In3+, and Ni2+. Luckily, the interference of metal ions can be eliminated by adding an appropriate masking agent [86]. On the other hand, due to the instability of oxidizing agent-hypochlorite used in the IB method, some transition metals, like Ir, Rh, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe3+ and Co3+, may adversely catalyze the decomposition of hypochlorite [87]. Pérez-Ramírez et al. [88] suggested that, for this ion interference, IB method can be applied in an alkaline solution and incubated with citrate buffer for 40 min to obtain an accurate ammonia quantification at 0.1 × 10−6 g mL−1-level. In addition, Zhang et al. [78] explored other limitations of spectrophotometric methods, including conductive carbon, organic solvents, and disturbance of containing NH x species. Conductive carbon itself may break down in an electrochemical process into some unknown substance (possible carbon nanoparticles or compounds) that acts as a disruptor in spectrophotometric methods. Some organic solvents commonly used for photocatalytic NRR sacrificial agents may react with colorimetric reagents to colored precipitation, such as amines, amides, aldehydes, acetones, and alcohols, leading to an overestimation of NH3 concentration. Also regrettably, some substance containing NH x species are unstable under UV-Vis light irradiation (200–800 nm) to decompose into ammonia, like oleyl amine, thioacetamide (TAA), and hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) [78]. As a result, it is suggested to avoid the utilization of reagents or catalytic materials containing NH x functional groups. Notably, during the determination process by spectrophotometric methods, it is necessary to control the time of color development and the order of reagent addition. Finally, UV-Vis spectrophotometer itself also dramatically influences the accurate quantification of ammonia, including photometric accuracy, instrument stability, low noise, high sensitivity, wavelength accuracy, and repeatability, etc. And we suggest that all quantitative experiments in one research project should be conducted on one instrument. 4.2 1H NMR method According to most NRR publications, 1H NMR method has gradually developed as a versatile quantification means for the detection of micromolar concentrations of ammonia. By 1H NMR method, ammonia (NH3) is usually quantified in the form of ammonium (NH4 +), which is more stable in solution. Generally speaking, 1H NMR spectrum mainly provides three important parameters: chemical shift, coupling constant, and peak area [89]. We usually locate the peak of NH3/ NH4 + by chemical shift and coupling constants and obtain the quantitative data of NH3/NH4 + by peak area. The quantification result is based on a quantitative comparison of the analyte signal with that of an internal standard [90]. By using a frequency-selective pulse sequence, this method is also efficient in quantifying ammonia content in a range of solutions in a variety of nondeuterated, nonaqueous, and aqueous solutions [91]. It offers the advantages of high sensitivity and reproducibility and does not need for NH3 transfer [92]. In order to obtain accurate 1H NMR quantitative data, we first need to find the correct attribution peak of ammonium, which needs to exclude the influence of impurity peak, and then accurate integration data of peak area corresponding to the ammonia yield is further required. But 1H NMR method is highly susceptible to experimental parameters, including pH, deuterated solvent, solution, analyte concentrations, etc. Zhang et al. [83] found, compared with the colorimetric method, 1H NMR method is less affected by pH changes under the circumstance of low-concentration products, which shows significant reproducibility and stability in solutions with different pH. However, the case for low-concentration ammonia dissolved in high-concentration solutions is still risky [83]. Prior to that, Simonov et al. [90] also inspected the influence of final pH on the NMR spectra of aqueous 10 μmol L−1 14NH4Cl. The work demonstrated when at low H2SO4 concentration ([H2SO4]), proton activity is insufficient to force the equilibrium to favor ammonium, hindering visibility of the corresponding triplet while too high [H2SO4] increased proton exchange, conversely decreasing the intensity of the ammonium signal [90]. It can be emphasized the importance of pH control in the final analysis samples on the exact ammonia quantification of 1H NMR method. Besides, similar to colorimetric assays, the containing-ammonia amount of samples needs to be strictly controlled in a reasonable range, compatible with nuclear magnetic resonance instruments. Otherwise, it will interfere with the sensitivity and accuracy of results. Another potential error responsible for the reliability of the NMR method can be assigned to deuterated solvents, which calibrate magnetic field fluctuations and drifts as well as the δ axis [88]. Significant and uncontrolled levels of hydrogen/deuterium (H/D) exchange will result in a rapid exchange of ammonium protons, forming some undetected ammonium analogs, such as ND4 + [93]. In that case, it is suggested to avoid the employment of deuterated solvents with any unstable deuterium, such as D2O and deuterated acetone, while solvents such as DMSO-d 6 and CDCl3 are preferred instead [3,90] ((Fig. 5(c))). In addition, the composition of the solution may affect the nuclear magnetic signal due to the possibly-carried electronic effect, inductive effect, hydrogen bond, etc. [94], thus generating interfering signals in the ammonium range. This adds to the difficulty in correctly distinguishing between ammonium and impurity peaks and complicates the integration of the peak area of ammonium. Regarding background contamination, the solution without ammonia still shows a weak peak signal of NH4 +. Worthy to note, Simonov's work contributed to the mitigation of this problem. They improved the resolution by optimizing the NMR deuterated solvent, given that the signal of pollutants distorted the triple signal of NH4 + [90]. What's more, some instrumental parameters, such as magnetic field strength, number of scans, and other key parameters, can also be amended to enhance product peak signal and improve resolution. Take magnetic field strength as an example, sometimes switching field strength may help obtain cleaner NMR spectra. The required high level of expertise and relatively low availability of NMR spectrometers with large magnetic field strength [90,91] (1H frequency above 600 MHz) also hampers the NMR method's reliability. 4.3 Isotope labeling method Aside from the Ar control experiment as a first control experiment, the necessity of 15N isotope experiment has been emphasized in many recent research papers or reviews [95–97]. In this qualification method, the control experiment should be exerted via 15N2 feed gas under the same condition as the 14N2 reduction experiment, so the amount of produced 15NH3 theoretically is equal to that of 14NH3 produced in the equivalent 14N2 reduction tests [98]. This method is more direct and accurate compared with other quantitative methods. As Chorkendorff et al. [71] stated, 15N isotope labeling method provides more definite proof to detect any ammonia originating from the electroreduction of N2. They even proposed a rigorous electrochemical ammonia synthesis protocol with quantitative isotope measurements to differentiate false positives from breakthrough results [71]. However, as gas source pollution mentioned above, isotope measurements with 15N2 are also heavily plagued by impure 15N2 gas feed, largely interfering with the accuracy of the controlled experiment [99]. A previous study by Wang et al. [100] reported that 15N2 gas of 0.87% impurities might result in the production of 3600 µg of ammonia or other nitrogenous substances per hour via bubbling at a rate of 10 mL min−1 for 28 h. This demonstrated that even impurity levels limited to a few ppm could be problematic [100]. Therefore, like 14N2, an isotope labeling experiment with 15N2 also requires strict control and purification procedures, including a nitrogen control experiment under open-circuit voltage for gas purity determination and purification before NRR experiment. Specific control and purification details to eliminate the quantification error, similar to those of 14N2 gas, can be seen in Section 2.3. Gas tightness assurance during nitrogen reduction tests is also applicable for the improved quantification of 15N isotope experiment here. What's more, to judge the real origin of ammonia produced in the NRR systems, the isotope labeling method is generally inseparable from the combination of other methods. These methods are mainly responsible for distinguishing 15NH3 and 14NH3, including mass spectrometry (MS) [79], infrared spectroscopy [101], and 1H NMR [71], among which the most convenient is 1H NMR method. The extra useful nature of 1H NMR method is to quantitatively and qualitatively distinguish between 14NH4 + (triplet) and 15NH4 + (doublet) [102]. ((Fig. 5(d))) Therefore, the disadvantages of 1H NMR affecting the precise quantification of ammonia will indirectly influence the validity of isotope labeling results, as Section 3.2 mentioned. Moreover, the composition of 15NH4 + product is temperature-sensitive and triple peaks of 14NH4 + may be detected in addition to the peaks of 15NH4 + after high-temperature distillation due to the isotope fractionation effect. Therefore, if high temperature treatment is involved during isotope detection, attention should be paid to this phenomenon [103]. Except for NMR, MS, especially in situ electrochemical MS, is widely used for NH3 determination in nitrogen fixation reaction like nitrogen or nitrate reduction reaction. But it cannot be ignored that this method also has the great potential to accurately quantify ammonia due to its low detection limit, particularly in combination with other methods, such as ion chromatography (IC) and gas or liquid chromatography (GC or LC). Mass spectrometers can be divided into high (R > 50000), medium (R = 10000–50000) and low (R ≤ 10000) resolution instruments according to their resolution. However, even in such advanced combination strategies, it is still difficult to quantify ammonia by evaluating the ratio of 14NH3 +/15NH3 + because 15NH4 + and H3O+ share the same nominal m/z. Therefore, for aqueous solutions in NRR systems, H2O will generate a high background signal in the MS spectrum, precluding robust quantification of the 15NH3 signal [104]. What's more, ammonia and ammonium ions are volatile and not easily detected by MS due to the low mass, so they usually need to be converted to stable compounds with higher molecular mass for more reliable analysis by derivatization reaction [96]. For LC-MS analysis, indophenol blue reagent is a typical derivating agent to form ammonia derivatives via the Berthelot reaction, according to the previous studies [96]. F. Dalleska's group [104] also ever simply mixed danyl chloride, widely used in amino acid derivations for fluorescence and MS, with NH4 + aqueous solution to generate ammonia derivatives for ultrahigh performance liquid chromatography (UPLC)-MS analysis. Similarly, for GC-MS analysis, Adam J. Rondinone et al. [79] used o-phenylphenol in a modified version to react with 15NH3 and 14NH3 into hexanol-soluble dye [79]. The MS spectrum peaks produced by different derivatives are generally at different locations due to the difference of derivating agents’ molecule mass. Nevertheless, the two fragmentation patterns of 14N and 15N are identical, where the 15N-containing fragments are shifted by +1 m/z (mass/charge ratio) compared to 14N fragments. Unfortunately, the reproducibility of quantification results is easily disturbed by the experimental setup and operation parameters in isotopic detection, such as the specification of analysis equipment, detection mode, and the composition and flow rate of mobile phases, etc. What's more, the detection solution's pH is influenced by the addition of derivating agents, it is sometimes too high to damage the separation column and cause permanent and irreversible damage to equipment. This will adversely affect the ability to identify and quantify the 14NH4 + and 15NH4 + [96]. Even worse, except for possible influence of subsequent MS and NMR, Simonov et al. [3] even posed a doubt: are the experiments using 15N2 reliable and sufficient to confirm the key results? According to their protocols, qualitative 15NH3 analyses only is unreliable, and a single 15N2 quantitative experiment under only one set of conditions might be reliable yet inconclusive. Only when 15N2 reduction quantitative data over time is in good agreement with the corresponding 14NRR based on strict and basically reasonable procedures and methods will the results of 15N isotope labeling method be believable. Last but not least, not only nitrogen source, for eNRR and pNRR with H2O towards ammonia, hydrogen source in ammonia tends to be ignored, which plays a crucial role in the reaction mechanism study and credible ammonia quantification of NRR. Similar to 15N isotope labeling method by 15N2 as nitrogen source to confirm the N source in NH3, it is still suitable to employ D isotope labeling method by D2O as proton source to understand hydrogen transfer pathways and further confirm the H source in NH3 [105]. The whole procedure to verify the source of H can refer to that of N source verification. To help intuitively understand quantitation methods for NH4 +, the recommended application scope of the above detection methods and some other typical quantitation methods is shown in Table 4 [83]. Another concern is that the results may not evaluate the nitrogen fixing performance thoroughly, although above mentioned quantification methods have an accurate quantification of ammonia. Because nitrogen is likely to be fixed in the other forms of byproducts with high additional value during the process of ammonia synthesis from N2 and H2O, such as N2H4, NO3 −, NO2 −, etc. Therefore, to have an overall assessment of nitrogen fixing performance of NRR catalysts, it is also essential to accurately quantify the concomitant byproducts. Given that the content of the above byproducts is also extremely low, it is applicable to select above several discussed quantification methods to do convincing quantitative tests of high value-added byproducts. Take hydrazine (N2H4), a common byproduct for an example, which is determined by means of Watt and Chrisp [106,107]. The p-C9H11NO (5.99 g), HCl (concentrated, 30 mL), and C2H5OH (300 mL) are mixed and used as a color reagent and the developed yellow color has been used as the basis for the development of a spectrophotometric method for the determination of hydrazine. And then 5 mL electrolytes from the reaction vessels are added into 5 mL prepared color reagents and stirred for more than ten minutes. The absorbance of the resulting solutions is measured at the range of 400–700 nm. While for other byproducts, like NO3 −, NO2 −, etc., their detection and quantification methods have also been reported [108]. 5 Summary and outlook Throughout the development of ammonia synthesis, it proceeds from large-scale production of ammonia by industrial Haber-Bosch process to small-scale ammonia synthesis by electrocatalytic/photocatalytic NRR synthesis in the laboratory. The experimental NRR method towards ammonia driven by clean energy has gradually entered the field of view of researchers with many advantages such as environmental and economic friendliness and controllable conditions. More and more researchers have carried out an in-depth exploration of it. As a result, the field has shown a trend of blowout development, in which catalysts of different performance emerge in an endless stream, components of reaction solutions are richer and more advanced, etc. Benefiting from this situation, the NRR system has been improved again and again, and the ammonia production rate has also been continuously updated and improved, according to a large number of literature records. Unfortunately, the yield of NRR to ammonia still remains at the nanomole/micromole level, well below that of the ammonia production scale of the Haber-Bosch process. In addition, the quantitative results are often accompanied by volatility, coupled with serious inclusion or attachment of polluted species from the air environment, such as catalysts, gas sources, air atmosphere, and so on. This leads to false-positive results and excessive FE, followed by growing controversy from the scientific community over the dependability of the NRR method. To find real highly active, selective, and efficient NRR systems, this review puts forward paradigm research and summarizes which potential factors may affect the final ammonia quantitation results–the most intuitive basis for NRR performance assessment. Here, these factors were divided into catalyst preparation pollution, pollution introduction in the experiment process, as well as the inherent defects of quantification methods, and some reported elimination ways were also attached. Due to the presence of nitrogen oxides and exogenous ammonia, once the catalyst is contaminated in the process of preparation and application, it is very likely to cause great damage to the final accurate quantification of ammonia yield. Reaction solution and nitrogen supply are reactant sources in NRR ammonia synthesis, which directly affects the yield of the product ammonia. It is important to consider their pollution condition. The devices used in the NRR test are also highly susceptible to contamination in the laboratory environment. What's more, the shortcomings of three frequently-used methods for ammonia quantification are enumerated in this paper, including spectrophotometric/colorimetric assays, 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR), and 15N isotope labeling method, respectively. Until now, scientific community has proposed the corresponding solving strategies from the existing protocols, including the commonly-used Ar blank experiment, some contamination determination and elimination methods, quantification method selection principles, and so on. For severe external nitrogenous species contamination, it can be relieved via a catalyst, solution, and gas purification, while for the intrinsic effect of ammonia quantification methods, a combination of different quantitate methods is an optional way to reduce error in final ammonia quantification for NRR systems. Several quantification methods are adopted in the order of spectrophotometry, NMR, and isotope labeling, to guarantee the consistency of ammonia quantification results and reliability of NRR performance. In addition, it is also very necessary to do some pre-treatments before NRR tests, such as thorough washing of catalysts and experimental device materials, etc. Based on the above discussion, we proposed a strict protocol for accurate ammonia quantification in NRR system, as shown in Fig. 6 . In the end, adhering to the concept of “larger base, smaller error,” we also hope to contribute promising suggestions that the actual ammonia production (non-specific production) could be further increased to reduce the influence of external pollution on the quantification results. The FE of NRR in some reported works has reached over 80%, much approaching the target set by the U.S. Department of Energy (90%). However, such high FE still leaves NYR at an extremely low level (< 100 μg h−1 g−1). This is not only inconducive to the accurate quantification of ammonia products but doomed to be unable to push eNRR or pNRR into practical application. Based on this, we propose the following proposals for the future NRR research: (1) Describing NYR in “μg h−1 cmelectrode −2“ rather than “μg h−1 gcatalyst −1“. In most existing NRR research, the catalyst loading on an electrode is usually less than 0.1 mg. Compared to the specific NYR based on the mass of the catalyst, the specific NYR based on the electrode area provides a more rapid measure of the catalyst's potential for large-scale application. (2) Using working electrodes with a large area. NRR research in existing laboratories typically employs working electrodes with an area of 1 cm2. In the future, we recommend trying to use a large area of the working electrode. This will produce more ammonia for accurate quantification and facilitate the preliminary evaluation of the potential industrial application of NRR system. (3) Pursuing high FE under higher current density. In most existing work, especially in aqueous eNRR and pNRR, such high FE is usually achieved at a low current density (< 1 mA cm−2). Once the working current is increased, the intensification of HER will lead to a rapid decrease in FE. However, such a low operating current is destined for a low NYR, which has little significance for NRR's practical application. In the future, we advocate the pursuit of higher FE at high current density. (4) Improving the catalytic activity of NRR catalysts. For eNRR and pNRR, ammonia yield is closely related to catalyst activity, which can be generally elevated from two aspects: increasing the intrinsic activity and number of active digits of catalysts. We believe that the future development direction of catalyst modification methods can be started from the aspects of cocatalyst design, semiconductor design, surface and interface regulation, etc. Electronic supporting information Supporting information is available in the online version of this article. Int. Ed., 2020, 59, 5350–5354. Chenglin Yan (College of Energy at Soochow University) is a Professor and Dean of the College of Energy at Soochow University in Suzhou, China. He received his Ph.D. from Dalian University of Technology in 2008. In 2011, he became a staff scientist and a group leader at the Institute for Integrative Nanoscience at the Leibniz Institute in Dresden (Germany). His primary research interests focus on electrochemical energy storage. Jianmei Lu (College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science at Soochow University) is a Professor of the College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Materials Science and Vice Chancellor of Soochow University. She received her PhD in polymer chemistry from Zhejiang University in 1999 and was appointed as professor of Soochow University in 2000. Her current research interests involve organic and polymer electronic memory functional materials synthesis, device design and mechanism research, adsorption performance and mechanism of adsorbent materials, treatment of industrial waste water and waste gas containing volatile organic compounds and synthesis of photocatalytic functional materials.

coredata.dc:description: As an essential raw material for fertilizer production and promising green fuels, ammonia is significant to the national economy and social development. Recently, nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) towards ammonia under mild conditions has received intensive attention due to environmental friendliness and low energy consumption, compared to the rigorous and contaminative Haber-Bosch process. However, as current research deepens, some fatal challenges emerged in this field–not only high volatility and low repeatability but false–positive results, casting serious doubts about its prospects. In this review, we summarized and discussed some potential factors that possibly induce false-positive results for accurate ammonia quantification, including the aspects of catalyst materials, experimental process, and quantification methods. And corresponding methods to eliminate these effects are also summarized. Furthermore, a promising protocol and several control principles are proposed to eliminate potential errors during ammonia quantification. This review establishes a paradigm base in NRR research field toward more accurate ammonia quantification.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Excluding false positives: A perspective toward credible ammonia quantification in nitrogen reduction reaction
